intro: Castanea crenata var. kawasei, commonly known as the Japanese chestnut, is a variant of the chestnut species native to Japan. It is a deciduous tree that typically grows to a height of 10–15 meters, featuring compound leaves with serrated edges. The plant produces spiny, cup-shaped fruits that contain one or two edible nuts. It thrives in temperate climates and is often found in forested areas with well-drained soil. The botanical characteristics of this variety make it an important species in both ecological and horticultural contexts.
